docs.lead_paragraph: Contradicting Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, Sgt. Christina Roy swore today that she had never considered an abortion, even though her 1996 pregnancy was unwanted and precluded the job ''opportunity of a lifetime'' on Sergeant Major McKinney's staff. ''I don't believe God gave us the authority to make or take a life,'' Sergeant Roy testified at the sergeant major's court-martial here.

headline.main: Ex-Top Soldier Is Contradicted By An Accuser

docs.abstract: Sgt Christine Roy testifies at court-martial of Sgt Maj Gene C McKinney; Roy, one of six women who have made accusations of sexual misconduct against McKinney, is the only one to report having sexual intercourse with him (S)
docs.snippet: Contradicting Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, Sgt. Christina Roy swore today that she had never considered an abortion, even though her 1996 pregnancy was unwanted and precluded the job ''opportunity of a lifetime'' on Sergeant Major McKinney's staff.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To make AIDS drugs more widely available in the third world, the pharmaceutical company Glaxo Wellcome said today that it would slash the price of AZT treatments for pregnant women in poor countries. Glaxo Wellcome agreed to the deal with United Nations health officials after recent research showing that short-term doses of AZT can halve the number of babies infected at birth from mothers carrying H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: AIDS Drug Cost to Be Cut for Poor Women

docs.abstract: Glaxo Wellcome pharmaceutical company says it will slash price of AZT treatments for pregnant women in poor countries after recent research showed that short-term doses of AZT can halve number of babies infected at birth from mothers carrying HIV, virus that causes AIDS; with 550,000 babies born to HIV-positive mothers each year in developing countries, decision could save thousands of young lives (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To prosecutors, as one of them says on tonight's ''48 Hours,'' it's ''a simple case of murder.'' To defense lawyers, the clients charged with killing their newborn babies are mentally ill. Viewers who see the young women on news and magazine programs, telling of secret pregnancies with deadly consequences, may find it hard to decide whether they are victims or monsters. The title of tonight's report, ''Fatal Mistake,'' is ambiguous. Does it refer to the common defense that the mother thought her baby was born dead, or is it a comment on the murder or manslaughter indictments of women who felt alone and desperate?

headline.main: The Search for Truth in the Killing of Newborns

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews Fatal Mistake, documentary in CBS-TV's 48 Hours news program examining cases of women whose newborns died after secret pregnancies and who have been charged with murder or manslaughter; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Under cross-examination in his court-martial, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney did not falter today in insisting that he had not made sexual advances toward subordinates. But some of the jurors focused, with startled expressions, over evidence of dozens of telephone calls between him and a young pregnant soldier.

headline.main: Court-Martial Shows Calls By Sergeant and an Accuser

docs.abstract: Sgt Maj Gene C McKinney, under cross-examination in his court-martial, insists that he had not made sexual advances toward subordinates; explains many telephone calls he made to Sgt Christine Roy as sign of his concern for unhappy soldier; Roy, young pregnant soldier, is only one among McKinney's six accusers who claims she had sexual relations with him; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark J. Green, New York City's Public Advocate, moved to stake out ground in the United States Senate race yesterday, decrying abuses by health maintenance organizations and advocating a hefty $1.50-per-pack increase in cigarette taxes to help discourage teen-agers from smoking. In what he described as the first of six major policy speeches, Mr. Green also endorsed a plan that would provide state and federally financed medical coverage for uninsured children and expectant mothers.

headline.main: Green States Policy, and It Is on Health Care

docs.abstract: NYC Public Advocate Mark J Green, in policy speech related to his candidacy for US Senate, decries abuses by health maintenance organizations and advocates hefty $1.50 per pack increase in cigarette taxes to help discourage teenagers from smoking; says he also endorses plan that would provide state and federally financed medical coverage for uninsured children and expectant mothers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a month of testimony at his court-martial here, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney took the stand today, defending his relationship with his accusers as characteristic of his leadership style of intensely personal interaction with soldiers. Unlike the other military witnesses, who sat stiffly on the stand and responded with clipped formality, Sergeant Major McKinney spoke in a relaxed conversational manner and gazed directly at the jurors.

headline.main: Ex-Top Soldier Takes Stand in Court-Martial

docs.abstract: Sgt Maj Gene C McKinney testifies in own defense in court-martial on sexual misconduct charges; denies all charges (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As reproductive technology has advanced, the law of supply and demand has inevitably clicked in. Some clinics have had trouble finding women to donate their eggs for implantation in infertile women. That has led to a medical and ethical debate over whether donors should charge for their eggs and, if so, how much. The St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., recently accelerated that debate by offering $5,000 for donors, double the rate of many clinics. A variety of experts were asked whether women should be permitted to sell their eggs on the open market: Robert Wright is the author of ''The Moral Animal: Evolutionary Psychology and Everyday Life.''

docs.lead_paragraph: CHOOSE any and all correct statements: People living in hot climates eat lots of highly seasoned foods because -- 1. Hot spices cool them down by making them sweat.

headline.main: Adding Cumin to the Curry: A Matter of Life and Death

docs.abstract: Cornell University researchers report that people who live in hot climates may like hot foods because spice plants contain powerful antibiotic chemicals capable of killing or suppressing bacteria and fungi that commonly contaminate and spoil foods and can poison those who eat them; spices that are prominent in traditional dishes from tropical and subtropical regions are used with much lighter hand, if at all, in countries and regions where climate is colder; chart compares use of various hot foods and spices in India and Norway (L)
